review_title: Great job for students who want some extra money, but are too busy for a job off campus
pros: I was a tutor in my dorm building because I lived in the international dorm already and there were a lot of international students that needed help writing papers in English. This was a perfect job for me because I had a full workload with my own classes and I was even working on my senior capstone so I did not have a lot of spare time to waste with a commute or long, irregular hours. This job was great for that and I learned that I am pretty good at teaching and I enjoyed it.
cons: The pay was not a lot, but because I only had to stay in the building I lived in, I definitely felt it was worth it. I got to do my own homework when I was "on call" and did not have a student, but things did pick up a lot near finals time. It was a little challenging to study for my own exams and help others, so I just had to manage my time effectively.

review_title: Ok to work here if you don't need a lot of money
pros: Very good environment at TTU, very good health insurance, after 5 years you are 100% vested in the state pension program, you can retire after 30 years of service,
cons: The pay at TTU for this job is horrible. The department is overstaffed. Some employees are required to work very hard while others are lacking in performance with little discipline. Very high politic level if you wish to pursue management positions which rarely become available. Lead positions pay $15,800 which is only $1,400 for much greater responsibility. If you make supervisor you get $25,500 for managing 30 people. This is sad pay for a “state job” as people like to stay. No training to advance your position. As of 2010 no pay raise in 4 years.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Cookeville, TN
pros: Obviously, a GA only works here because it pays for tuition. It does that well. Some departments pay considerably less than this a month however, so check on that. Supervision is light in my department. I usually get a lot of freedom to run classes how I want.
cons: Graduate students in general seem underpaid for what they do. I am expected to teach 20 hours a week and still do research for free just because I'm an academic who is supposed to love it. When considering I could make easily 4x as much doing half the work in industry, this seems a problem.

pros: Great students, the majority of whom are engaged and eager to learn. It's a quiet mostly commuter campus with very few high level issues and the small on campus population give it a close knit feel. I built a great relationship with my Faculty Head, and the living learning villages have a lot of resources and it's great to have a professor to work with on living learning who is right down the hall. Overall, TN Tech is an institution that is traditional but also laid back. The surrounding town has a nice relationship with the institution and many places have discounts. and will collaborate with programming or other student initiatives.
cons: Hall Directors aren't included in department decisions. I understand that Hall Directors are pretty low in the organizational chart, but there was a constant level of condescension and lack of caring that made the department culture miserable. Students were Hall Directors at one time and a parental culture of  "do and don't question"  and a lack of being treated as a professional very much  still exists  The majority of decisions are made  without input and  handed down in the middle of the week. Any suggestions or questioning of practices is discouraged. Assistant Directors even split up professional staffs for meetings because in their words: "they felt threatened". As a whole, communication is inconsistent, secretive and usually comes as a mandate. I've heard "I need XYZ" by the end of the day" on many occasions and have been sent scrambling to complete tasks at a moment's notice .  Residence Life comes with su[roses and unexpected moments but many times I've been sent running by disorganization and demands instead of a ringing duty phone. Training for students and staff, when it does exist,  is highly unorganized and little time is put in.  A culture very much exists of "my way or the highway" when it comes to the Director and he rarely communicates with Hall Directors. There is a high resistance to anything new or technologically related and a priority is made to keep anything as cheap as possible.  Lastly, work life balance isn't valued. RAs are permitted to call you personally ( not the duty phone) whenever the have an issue and you are required to respond to your building 24/7.  You will also be requested to do trainings, check email, etc on the weekends

review_title: TN Tech is a place you can really feel at home.
pros: They are generous, and understanding. I believe it is very rewarding working of students in college. The campus is beautiful and makes me smile each day when I step out of my vehicle.
cons: It rains all the time. But as long as you are prepared you can handle it! Also it all depends what department you work in, I worked in one office i quit the week after we got a new supervisor because he was a jerk, but moved to a different office and loved everyone!

review_title: Work in your own little world and never hear from senior staff
pros: Great college atmosphere.  Good people working there. Budgets are all over the place and it's always hard to know if you'll ever have the money to do something needed.
cons: Extremely below market pay for administration and support staff.  Most senior staff are shut off from the world. Everyone works in their own little silo. A lot of self-described lazy faculty.

pros: Good town good school, nice folks, felt like part of the family. Lots of flexibility based on school schedule for workers
cons: not really any cons, again, it was a great experience, great co-workers and supervisors and great location. I guess pay could be more but that is true with any job

review_title: I have worked here for 14 years, and I regret giving such a low review.
pros:
--great students
--great colleagues 
--great campus
--great Cookeville community 
--the academic freedoms and creative opportunities for faculty remain a strength
cons:
--I would've given a much more sympathetic ranking before the recent change in upper administration
--New senior administration has resulted in a hiring & firing spree
--Custodial staff recently outsourced
--too many adjunct faculty

review_title: Nice location, good learning environment, naive research culture.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cookeville, TN
pros: Located at a small and inexpensive city of Cookeville. The stipend from the graduate assistantship is more than enough to survive plus you don't have to worry about paying the tuitions if you have full assistantship.
cons: Some professors tend to set unrealistic goals for the graduate assistants. Specially if you are a graduate research assistant, if the team is bad and the professor sadistic, then you are out of luck.
